docs.lead_paragraph: The following is the second in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren't, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.Berhene Gabraselase is sitting under the shiny tin roof of the Koraro health center's waiting area, fidgeting nervously with his scarf and glancing expectantly at the clinic's closed door every few seconds. His 19 year-old sister Ngisti is in there, undergoing treatment for an advanced case of malaria, and he's worried. "We use the net of course," he says, referring to the free mosquito-proof bed nets provided by the MVP. "I don't know how this happened."Berhene isn't feeling too well himself: when he woke up to find his sister's condition deteriorating, he got moving immediately, too hurried to eat breakfast. He spent much of the three hour trek to the center carrying his sister on his back.

headline.main: Health issues in a Millennium Village

docs.abstract: Guest blogger Jeff Marlow, a graduate student, writes a series of progress reports on Koraro, Ethiopia, one of 13 sites undergoing development courtesy of the Millennium Village Project.
docs.snippet: Guest blogger Jeff Marlow, a graduate student, writes a series of progress reports on Koraro, Ethiopia, one of 13 sites undergoing development courtesy of the Millennium Village Project.
